data.title: School of Arts and Sciences
data.meta_description: At Ottawa University, you will be taught by professional musicians who are committed to working with you take your current musical skills and knowledge to new heights
data.text:
Dr. Kevin Marét is the Dean of Arts and Sciences and Associate Professor of Music at Ottawa University. Marét conducts the University Wind Ensemble and teaches various music courses. Previously, Dr. Marét served as the Chair of the Creative Arts Division, the Interim Academic Dean at the Ottawa Campus, and the Academic Dean for OU Online. Dr. Marét served as the Fine Arts Coordinator for the Topeka Public School District, taught band in Missouri, instructed courses at the University of Missouri-Kansas City, was adjunct faculty at Grace University, Northwest Missouri State University, and was the Assistant Director of Bands and Director of Percussion Studies at McKendree University. His performance credits include the "United States Air Force Heartland of America Band" at Offutt AFB, Principal Percussionist with the Sioux City Symphony, and regular performances with the Kansas City, Omaha, and Lincoln Symphonies. His military band Sidewinder has performed on "The Ellen Show", "Entertainment Tonight”, "Fox and Friends”, and at the White House. Marét has performed with Placido Domingo, Patti LuPone, Idina Menzel, and Tommy Tune. His compositions can be heard in commercials, movie trailers, and television shows.

Dr. Marét holds a Bachelor of Music Education Degree from Northwest Missouri State University, a Master of Music Education Degree, and a Doctorate in Musical Arts - Percussion Performance Degree from the Conservatory of Music and Dance at the University of Missouri-Kansas City.

Performer, composer, arranger, educator and arts administrator Dan Thomas has received countless performance awards, and has performed, recorded and presented with some of the most influential jazz artists and pedagogues in nearly every state in the continental US, Canada, and abroad. Thomas’ CDs, City Scope, Musical Sanctuary and Voyage continue to receive critical acclaim, and acknowledgement on the national airplay charts.

Thomas has held previous appointments having served as the Executive Director and CEO of the Kansas City Jazz Orchestra. For nearly two decades, he served on the Doctoral faculty and as the co-chair of the Jazz Studies Program at UMKC’s Conservatory of Music and Dance with Bobby Watson. His students perform throughout the globe and teach at the highest levels, and have appeared many times at the Kennedy Center’s Betty Carter’s Jazz Ahead program, Jazz Port Townsend workshops, the Monterey Jazz Festival, and JEN. Students have been recognized in numerous jazz competitions and received many awards, notably in Downbeat, by Thelonious Monk, MTNA, Yamaha, ITG, Name, Music for All, Grammy, Bard Summer Jazz Academy (JALCO), the National Youth Orchestra and the Vandoren jazz saxophone competition, among other.

Thomas holds performing artist/educator endorsements with Yamaha, Vandoren, Locoparasaxo, WeWOOD and Roo Pads.

Bobby Watson sits among the pantheon of present-day jazz greats both as performer and composer. Born in Lawrence, Kan., his career now spans more than four decades. A multi-GRAMMY®-nominated saxophonist, composer, bandleader, educator and producer, Watson trained formally at the University of Miami and then, from 1977-81, earned his “doctorate” as musical director of Art Blakey’s Jazz Messengers. During his four-plus years with the legendary drummer, the saxophonist contributed to 14 Jazz Messengers recordings — more than anyone else in the group’s 35-year (1955-90) storied history.

Early on, in addition to Blakey, the saxophonist also worked with notable jazz icons and elder statesmen such as Max Roach, Louis Hayes, George Coleman and Sam Rivers, as well as sharing music experiences with innumerable noteworthy peers and colleagues as well as legendary vocalists such as Joe Williams, Lou Rawls, Betty Carter, Dianne Reeves and Carmen Lundy.

Virtually simultaneously, Watson also issued several other titles such as Love Remains (Red), the saxophonist’s now-classic 1986 release. The recording, recognized by the Penguin Guide to Jazz (Penguin; 7 th Ed.), received the publication’s highest rating, cited in the edition as a part of its “core collection” joining other entries as a title any jazz aficionado should own. Year of the Rabbit, a musical tribute to Johnny Hodges, followed in 1989; Tailor Made, the Watson-led GRAMMY®-nominated all-star big band in 1993; he also released multiple titles by the four-horn 29th Street Saxophone Quartet and composed music for the Robert De Niro-directed film, A Bronx Tale (1993).

To read more visit Bobbywatson.com

MacKenzie Wright received her undergraduate degree in music from Ohio Wesleyan University and master’s degree from the California Institute of the Arts. She is currently pursuing a Ph.D. in music education with an emphasis on vocal pedagogy at the University of Kansas where she serves as a graduate teaching assistant.

Ms. Wright teaches courses in vocal pedagogy and choral methods and also maintains private and collegiate voice studios. She has been a presenter at the Kansas Music Educators Association and continues to be an active researcher, focusing on improvisation in communities.

In addition to her work as an educator, Ms. Wright maintains an active performing career as a vocalist, pianist, and organist. Her performing engagements have included the American Church in London, National Methodist Church, the Los Angeles Suzuki Festival, the National American Choral Directors Association National Convention, Charlotte Street Foundation, and ArtsKC.

Katie Benyo received her Masters in Violin Performance from The University of Missouri, Kansas City. She not only performs and teaches classical music, she has also performed and recorded in many different styles of music including country, traditional Americana, jazz, fiddle, bluegrass, pop and rock. She performed at the Major League Baseball World Series, the American Royal World Series of BBQ, the Kauffman Center for the Performing Arts, and with Lindsey Stirling, 2Cellos and Evanescence. She uses her eclectic performing background to inspire students no matter their musical interests. She studied pedagogy at Indiana University's retreat for Violin and Viola teachers under Mimi Zweig, and she taught at the international music festival, VerArte in Arequipa, Peru.

Stan was born into a musical family and he began his professional

career at age 15 by playing “tailgate” trombone in his Dad’s Dixieland

Band. After college, where he earned a Bachelor’s of Music Eduacation

and a Master’s in Solo Performance, Stan entered the U.S. Air Force Band

program. During his Air Force career, he was trombone soloist and lead

player with various groups. Stan arrived on the Portland, OR scene in

the mid ‘90s and has become one of the most active jazz trombonists in

the area, performing with a full spectrum of musical groups throughout

the United States.

Stan was on the music faculty at Willamette University from Sep. 1995-

May 2012 and in the fall term, 2005, he also joined the jazz faculty at

Mt. Hood Community College until retiring from higher education in

2012. He continues to be an active performer, composer, and arranger,

appearing throughout the Northwest as a Clinician and Performer.

Based in Kansas City, bassist Sam Copeland’s artistic career spans performance in jazz and classical music, composition, arranging, and education.

Sam is one of the most sought-after jazz bassists in the region. Sam serves as bassist in Riff Generation, a ten-piece jazz collective sponsored by the Kansas City Jazz Orchestra, dedicated to performing original music and exploring the relationship between composed and improvised modes of music making. An active session musician, Sam has recorded with William Flynn, Nate Nall, Arthur White, and many others. Sam's own group, Sam Copeland Quartet, has performed at the Capital Jazz Fest in Jefferson City, MO and the Blue Note Jazz Fest in Columbia, MO. Sam has performed and recorded with numerous other local, regional, and international artists, including Matt Otto, Dan Thomas, Roger Wilder, Rob Scheps, Danny Embrey, Jim Lower, Bobby Watson, and many more.

As a classical musician, Sam has performed professionally in many orchestral, chamber, and solo settings. He performs frequently with Lyric Opera of Kansas City, Midwest Chamber Ensemble. Sam has served as bassist for Missouri Symphony Society in Columbia, MO, and has frequently subbed for Springfield Symphony in Springfield, MO.

Also a prolific composer and arranger, Sam's music has been performed and recorded by numerous diverse professional and collegiate ensembles. His compositions for big band have been performed or recorded by student and professional jazz ensembles including the KC-based Jim Lower Jazz Orchestra, UMKC Jazz Ensemble, University Of Missouri Concert Jazz Band, Taneycomo Festival Jazz Orchestra, and others. Sam is constantly writing new compositions for Riff Generation and for his own quartet.

A dedicated music educator, Sam teaches all levels from beginning through collegiate. He has served as bass instructor at Ottawa University in Ottawa, Kansas, and at Bethel College in North Newton, Kansas. Sam is director of string orchestras in multiple schools in Blue Valley School District in Overland Park, Kansas. Also a frequent clinician, Sam teaches clinics annually at Olathe Bass Workshop, Kansas City Bass Workshop, and other clinics.

Sam holds a Master of Arts in Music degree from University of Missouri–Kansas City, a Bachelor of Music degree in Double Bass Performance from University of Missouri–Columbia, and a Master of Arts in Teaching degree from Pittsburg State University. His primary teachers and mentors include Jeff Kail, James Albright, and Sue Stubbs.

Sam Fleming is known throughout the United States and parts of South America as a conductor, composer, organist, and music educator. He has held various conducting positions with community, church, and school ensembles. He is experienced as a conductor equally on the concert stage, in worship, and in musical theatre. As an organist, Fleming has performed throughout the United States as a soloist and with several choral ensembles and chamber groups. Fleming’s compositions have been commissioned and premiered by various ensembles including Brigham Young University-Idaho, Illinois State University, the Fountain of the Sun Community Chorus and the Salonnieres Chamber Ensemble of Phoenix, Arizona. His works are published through his own publishing company, SFM Publishing.

Fleming currently serves as Director of Music and Organist at Episcopal Church of the Good Shepherd in Kansas City, Missouri and is on the faculty of Ottawa University in Ottawa, Kansas. Prior to his appointment at Good Shepherd, he served as Director of Worship and Arts/Organist at First United Methodist Church in Florence, Alabama and as an adjunct professor in the keyboard and choral areas at the University of North Alabama. Additionally Fleming maintains a private studio of organ, piano, conducting, composition, and voice students.

Fleming graduated with a Master of Music degree in Choral Conducting from Illinois State University and a Bachelor of Musical Arts degree in Organ Performance and Music Composition from Brigham Young University-Idaho. He is currently pursuing a Doctor of Musical Arts degree at the University of Kansas in Choral Conducting and Church Music. Sam is a member of the American Guild of Organists (AGO), American Choral Directors Association (ACDA), American Society of Composers, Authors, and Publishers (ASCAP), and Pi Kappa Lambda Music Honor Society. He currently resides in Kansas City, Missouri with his family.

Matt has been a top-tier guitarist in Kansas City for over 20 years. In addition to working frequently with his own jazz trio and quartet, Matt is a vital fixture in at least 25 of Kansas City’s premier music ensembles. The reasons that he remains in such demand as a performer and educator are that he is uniquely gifted, reliable, and diligent. Additionally, his aptitude for performing and teaching various styles of music makes him an invaluable asset in any musical situation and institution.

In addition to performing consistently and frequently around the greater Kansas City metropolitan area for over 20 years, Matt has performed overseas in Paris, Porto Alegre, Rio, Salvador, and Novo Hamburgo. While in the Brazilian cities of Porto Alegre and Rio, Matt taught masterclasses at their local universities.

Matt’s impeccable skill as a guitarist and his wealth of experience as a private jazz instructor make him a valuable asset to the Ottawa University music faculty.

Forest Stewart's experience includes work on both French horn and electric bass. Forest is bassist and musical director for a popular and well-known singer in the Kansas City area, Ida McBeth and Friends, plays bass with Dan Thomas and Voyage, Cubanisms, and has worked extensively with Orquesta Alto Maiz, "the Salsa Band". On horn, Forest has performed with the Des Moines Symphony, the Rochester Orchestra and Chorale, the Waterloo/Cedar Falls Symphony Orchestra, and currently plays with Lee’s Summit Symphony and the People’s Liberation Big Band under the direction of Brad Cox. Forest has performed in New York, Las Vegas, Denver, Minneapolis/St. Paul, in cities throughout Germany and Italy, and at festivals in Chicago, Los Angeles, Geneva, Montreaux, Den Haag and Cuba.

Artists with whom Forest has performed include Nick Brignola, Steve Cardenas, Richie Cole, Jerry Coker, Garry Dial, John Fedchock, Bruce Forman, Mike Freeman, Bill Goodwin, Steve Houghton, Arnie Lawrence, David Liebman, Chip McNeal, Jim McNeely, Roy Meriwether, Dick Oatts, Kim Park, Jack Peterson, Jim Piu, Joe Porcaro, Emil Richards, Bobby Shew, Marvin Stam, Jerry Steinholtz, Clark Terry, Dan Thomas, Phil Upchurch, Bobby Watson, Jiggs Wiggums, and the Paul Winter Consort.

Ivy Lu Wang is an active pianist, chamber musician, lecturer, teacher, and founder of the Conero International Piano Festival & Competition and the International Piano Professionals Association (IPPA). As an inspiring lecturer and teacher, Wang is frequently invited to give concerts, masterclasses, and lectures at many different universities and piano schools. Wang's academic research specialty is injury prevention. She graduated with honors from University of Kansas with her doctoral Dissertation “Applying the Rotation Principle to Avoid Injury in Piano Practice”. In her performance career, Wang has won multiple competition prizes, including the first prize in the 2011 Zhong-sin International Music Competition in Singapore, where she was invited to perform in the award ceremony with the jury.
